revisions.rev:
'''List of successful U-boat commanders''' contains lists of the most successful [[Germany|German]] [[U-boat]] [[commander]]s in the two [[World War]]s based on total [[tonnage]].
The tonnage figures (and sometimes the number of ships sunk) is still being debated among historians. This is often due to [[convoy]] battles at night when an attacking "[[Wolfpack (naval tactic)|wolfpack]]" fired [[torpedo]]es into the convoy and two commanders claimed the same ship. Although post-war research has eliminated most of those doubtful victims, there are still some in question.
== World War I == This list contains the most successful German U-boats commanders during the [[First World War]] based on total tonnage. Only sunk commercial vessels are included, not military ([[warships]]) nor damaged ships.
{| class="wikitable" width="100%" |+ Top-scoring U-boat commanders of World War I |- ! # ! Commander ! Patrols ! Ships sunk ! width="100px" | Tonnage ! Notes ! width="110px" | Picture |- | 1 | [[Lothar von Arnauld de la PeriÃ¨re]] | 15 | 194 | 453,716 tons | Lothar von Arnauld de la PeriÃ¨re (1886–1941) was the most successful U-boat commander of World War I and of any submarine commander in history. Between 1915 and 1918, he made 14 patrols in command of {{SMU|U-35||2}}, sinking 189 merchant vessels and two gunboats. He transferred to {{SMU|U-139||2}} in May 1918 and sank a further five merchant ships, making 194 ships sunk totalling 453,716 GRT. After serving as an instructor in the [[Turkish Navy]] between 1932–1938, he returned to the ''[[Kriegsmarine]]'' and during World War II served as naval commandant for western France with the rank of ''[[Vizeadmiral]]''. He was killed in February 1941 when his aircraft crashed on take off at [[Paris â Le Bourget Airport|Le Bourget Airport, Paris]]. | [[File:Lothar von Arnauld de la PeriÃ¨re.jpg|100px|Lothar von Arnauld de la PeriÃ¨re]] |- | 2 | [[Walther Forstmann]] | 47 | 146 | 384,300 tons | Walther Forstmann (1883–1973) commanded {{SMU|U-12|Germany|2}} and {{SMU|U-39||2}} on 47 patrols and sank 146 ships for a total of 384,304 GRT. In 1921 he qualified as an [[lawyer|attorney]] and worked in the steel and coal industries, as well as being active in the [[German People's Party]]. Forstmann served on the staff of the ''[[Kriegsmarine]]'' during World War II. | [[File:Forstmann12.JPG|100px|Walther Forstmann]] |- | 3 | [[Max Valentiner]] | * | 150 | 299,300 tons | Max Valentiner (1883–1949) commanded {{SMU|U-38||2}} and {{SMU|U-157||2}}, and sank 150 ships for a total of 299,300 GRT. Branded a "war criminal" by the Allies for a series of incidents, including the sinking of {{SS|Persia|1900|6}}, Valentiner went into hiding for a while at the end of the war. During World War II, Valentiner was commander of a unit inspecting new U-boats before commissioning. | [[File:Max Valentiner.jpg|100px|Max Valentiner]] |- | 4 | [[Otto Steinbrinck]] | * | * | 231,614 tons | Otto Steinbrinck (1888–1949) commanded several submarines during World War I, sinking a total of 231,614 GRT of shipping. After the war he worked in the iron and steel industry. Steinbrinck joined the [[Nazi Party]] in 1933, and became a member of the [[Schutzstaffel|SS]], rising to the rank of ''[[BrigadefÃ¼hrer]]'', while remaining active in industry. In 1945, he was arrested and faced charges at the [[Flick Trial]]. In December 1947, he was sentenced to six years imprisonment in [[Landsberg Prison]], but died two years into his sentence. | |- | 5 | [[Hans Rose]] | * | 79 | 213,900 tons | Hans Rose (1885–1969) commanded {{SMU|U-53||2}} between 1916–1918, sinking 79 merchant ships for a total of 213,987 GRT, as well as the {{USS|Jacob Jones|DD-61|6}}, the first American [[destroyer]] to be lost during the war. Rose commanded a U-boat training unit in 1940. | [[File:Hans Rose.jpg|100px|Hans Rose]] |- | 6 | [[Walther Schwieger]] | 34 | 49 | 183,883 tons | Schwieger (1885–1917) commanded the {{SMU|U-14|Germany|2}}, {{SMU|U-20||2}} and {{SMU|U-88||2}}, sinking 49 ships for a total of 183,883 GRT in 34 patrols. One of these was passenger liner {{RMS|Lusitania}}, which led to the United States' eventual entry into the war. Schwieger was killed when ''U-88'' was sunk by a British mine off the Dutch coast in September 1917. | [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 134-C1831, KapitÃ¤nleutnant Walther Schwieger.jpg|100px|Walther Schwieger]] |- | 7 | [[Reinhold Saltzwedel]] | * | 111 | 170,526 tons | Reinhold Saltzwedel (1889–1917) commanded six U-boats during World War I, sinking 111 merchant vessels for a total of 170,526 GRT. He was killed in December 1917 when {{SMU|UB-81||2}} was sunk by a mine off the [[Isle of Wight]]. | [[File:Reinhold Saltzwedel.jpg|100px|Reinhold Saltzwedel]] |- | 8 | [[Johannes Lohs]] | * | * | 165,000 tons | Johannes Lohs (1889–1918) commanded {{SMU|UC-75||2}} and {{SMU|UB-57||2}}, and sank a total of 165,000 GRT of shipping. Lohs was killed when ''UB-57'' was lost in the [[North Sea]] in August 1918. | |- | 9 | [[Waldemar Kophamel]] | * | 54 | 148,852 tons | Waldemar Kophamel (1880–1934) commanded {{SMU|U-35||2}} and {{SMU|U-140||2}}, and sank 54 ships for a total of 148,852 GRT. | |- | 10 | [[Otto Schultze]] | * | 53 | 132,531 tons | Otto Schultze (1884–1966) commanded {{SMU|U-63||2}} and sank 52 ships for a total of 132,531 GRT plus one warship for a further 5,250 GRT.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://uboat.net/wwi/men/commanders/commander.php?officer=313 |title=''KapitÃ¤nleutnant '' Otto Schultze |work=uboat.net |accessdate=5 April 2011}}</ref> | <!-- Do NOT place non-free media here --> |}
== World War II == This list contains the most successful German U-boats commanders during the [[Second World War]] based on total tonnage. Only sunk commercial vessels are included, not military ([[warships]]) nor damaged ships.
With a higher score than Britainâs [[Malcolm David Wanklyn|Wanklyn]], in [[HMS Upholder (P37)|HMS ''Upholder'']], or Americaâs [[Richard O'Kane|OâKane]] in [[USS Tang (SS-306)|USS ''Tang'']] (both later sunk), [[Gianfranco Gazzana-Priaroggia]] and ''[[Italian submarine Leonardo da Vinci|Leonardo da Vinci]]'' were the most successful non-German submariner and submarine in the conflict.<ref>Blair p 740</ref>
But the '''Aces of the Deep'''{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}} were the ten [[Germany|German]] [[U-Boat]] commanders during [[World War II]] who sank the most enemy merchant ships during their naval services, ranked according to the total tonnage of the ships they sank. The term is related to [[flying ace]]{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}}, a [[World War I]] name for a pilot who shot down five or more enemy planes. The currently accepted list is as follows:
{| class="wikitable" width="100%" |+ Top-scoring U-boat commanders of World War II |- ! # ! Commander ! Patrols ! Ships sunk ! width="100px" | Tonnage ! Notes ! width="110px" | Picture |- | 1 | [[Otto Kretschmer]] | 16 | 47 | 273,043 tons | Otto Kretschmer (1912–1998) was the most successful of the World War II Aces of the Deep. As commander of {{GS|U-35|1936|2}}, {{GS|U-23|1936|2}} and {{GS|U-99|1940|2}} he sank 47 merchant ships totalling 272,043 tons in a remarkably short period of time, being captured in March 1941 and spending the rest of the war in the [[Bowmanville POW camp]], [[Canada]]. After the war, he rejoined the ''[[Bundesmarine]]'', and became the Chief of Staff of the NATO Command [[Allied Forces Baltic Approaches|COMNAVBALTAP]] in May 1965. He retired in September 1970 with a rank of ''[[Flottillenadmiral]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/kretschmer.htm |title=''FregattenkapitÃ¤n'' Otto Kretschmer |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | [[File:Otto Kretschmer.jpg|100px|Otto Kretschmer]] |- | 2 | [[Wolfgang LÃ¼th]] | 15 | 46 | 225,204 tons | Wolfgang LÃ¼th (1913–1945) was given command of {{GS|U-9|1935|2}} in December 1939, going on to command {{GS|U-13|1935|2}}, {{GS|U-138|1940|2}}, {{GS|U-43|1939|2}} and {{GS|U-181||2}}, and sinking 46 merchant ships for a total 225,204 tons in 15 patrols, including one of 205 days, the second longest of the war. In January 1944 LÃ¼th took command of ''[[22nd U-boat Flotilla]]'', before being appointed commander of the ''[[Naval Academy at MÃ¼rwik|Marineschule MÃ¼rwik]]'' in July. LÃ¼th was mistakenly shot and killed by a German sentry on 13 May 1945.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/luth.htm |title=''KapitÃ¤n zur See'' Wolfgang LÃ¼th |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | [[File:Wolfgang LÃ¼th.jpg|100px|Wolfgang LÃ¼th]] |- | 3 | [[Erich Topp]] | 12 | 35 | 197,460 tons | Erich Topp (1914–2005) commanded {{GS|U-57|1938|2}} and {{GS|U-552||2}} in 1940–1941, and sank 35 merchant ships for a total of 197,460 tons. He commanded the tactical training unit ''[[27th U-boat Flotilla]]'' from late 1942, and served briefly as commander of the [[German Type XXI submarine|Type XXI]] ''Elektroboote'' {{GS|U-3010||2}} and {{GS|U-2513||2}} just before the end of the war. He rejoined the ''[[Bundesmarine]]'' in 1956, reaching the rank of ''[[Konteradmiral]]'' before retiring in 1969.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/topp.htm |title=''Konteradmiral'' Erich Topp |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | [[File:Erich Topp.jpg|100px|Erich Topp]] |- | 4 | [[Heinrich Liebe]] | 9 | 34 | 187,267 tons | Heinrich Liebe (1908–1997) commanded {{GS|U-38|1938|2}} between 1938–1941, sinking 34 ships for a total of 187,267 GRT. In 1941 Liebe was assigned to the staff of ''[[Oberkommando der Marine]]'', and from August 1944 was on the staff of the [[Befehlshaber der U-Boote|BdU]]. After the war Liebe returned to his hometown in the [[Soviet occupation zone|Soviet sector]]. As he refused to train Soviet submariners, he was allowed only a series of menial occupations.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/liebe.htm |title=''FregattenkapitÃ¤n'' Heinrich Liebe |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | [[File:Heinrich Liebe.jpg|100px|Heinrich Liebe]] |- | 5 | [[Viktor SchÃ¼tze]] | 7 | 35 | 180,073 tons | Viktor SchÃ¼tze (1906–1950) commanded {{GS|U-25|1936|2}} and {{GS|U-103|1940|2}}, sinking 35 merchant ships totalling 180,073 tons, before being appointed commander of ''[[2nd U-boat Flotilla]]'' in August 1941. He became the ''[[FÃ¼hrer der U-Boote|FdU]] Ausbildungsflottillen'' (Commander of the Training Flotillas) in the [[Baltic Sea]] in March 1943. He spent a year in Allied captivity after the war.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/schuetze.htm |title=''KapitÃ¤n zur See'' Viktor SchÃ¼tze |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | <!-- Do NOT place non-free media here --> |- | 6 | [[Heinrich Lehmann-Willenbrock]] | 10 | 25 | 179,125 tons | Heinrich Lehmann-Willenbrock (1911–1986) commanded the {{GS|U-8|1935|2}}, {{GS|U-5|1935|2}} and {{GS|U-96|1940|2}}, sinking 25 merchant ships for a total of 179,125 tons. In May 1942 Willenbrock took command of ''[[9th U-boat Flotilla]]'', transferring to ''[[11th U-boat Flotilla]]'' in December 1944. After spending a year in captivity after the [[Victory in Europe Day|German surrender]], Willenbrock served as captain on merchant ships, and from 1964 commanded the German nuclear-powered freighter ''[[Otto Hahn (ship)|Otto Hahn]]''. Willenbrock acted as advisor to the film ''[[Das Boot]]'', based on an account of one of his own war patrols in ''U-96''.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/willenbrock.htm |title=''FregattenkapitÃ¤n'' Heinrich Lehmann-Willenbrock |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010}}</ref> | [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 101II-MW-3483-05, Heinrich Lehmann-Willenbrock.jpg|100px|Heinrich Lehmann-Willenbrock]] |- | 7 | [[Karl-Friedrich Merten]] | 5 | 27 | 170,151 tons | Karl-Friedrich Merten (1905–1993), in command of {{GS|U-68|1940|2}}, sailed in five patrols in 1941–1942 sinking 27 ships for a total of 170,151 tons. He commanded ''[[26th U-boat Flotilla]]'' in early 1943, and this and other training appointments curtailed his operational career. After the war he made a new career in shipbuilding.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/merten.htm |title=''KapitÃ¤n zur See'' Karl-Friedrich Merten |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | [[File:Karl-Friedrich Merten.jpg|100px|Karl-Friedrich Merten]] |- | 8 | [[Herbert Schultze]] | 8 | 26 | 169,709 tons | Herbert Schultze (1909–1987) commissioned {{GS|U-48|1939|2}} in 1939, and in eight patrols sank 26 merchant ships for a total of 169,709 tons. Schultze took command of ''[[3rd U-boat Flotilla]]'' in July 1941, until joining the staff of ''Marinegruppe Nord'' in March 1942. In December 1942 he was assigned to the staff of Admiral [[Karl DÃ¶nitz]]. In March 1944 he was assigned to ''[[Naval Academy at MÃ¼rwik|Marineschule MÃ¼rwik]]'', where he remained until the end of the war. In 1956 Schultze joined the ''[[Bundesmarine]]'' and served in a series of staff positions until 1968.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/schultze.htm |title=''KorvettenkapitÃ¤n'' Herbert Schultze |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | [[File:Herbert Schultze.jpg|100px|Herbert Schultze]] |- | 9 | [[GÃ¼nther Prien]] | 10 | 30 | 162,769 tons | GÃ¼nther Prien (1908–1941) was given command of {{GS|U-47|1938|2}} in December 1938, and sank over 30 Allied merchant ships for a total of 162,769 GRT. His most famous exploit was infiltrating the British [[Home Fleet]]'s base at [[Scapa Flow]] in October 1939 and sinking the battleship {{HMS|Royal Oak|08|6}} - which won him the [[Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross]], the first U-boat commander to do so. Prien was lost when ''U-47'' went missing on 7 March 1941 during an attack on [[Convoy OB 293]] south of [[Iceland]].<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/prien.htm |title=''KorvettenkapitÃ¤n'' GÃ¼nther Prien |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | [[File:GÃ¼nther Prien.jpg|100px|GÃ¼nther Prien]] |- | 10 | [[Georg Lassen]] | 4 | 26 | 156,082 tons | Georg Lassen (1915–) took command of {{GS|U-160|1941|2}} and sailed on four combat patrols in 1942 and 1943, sinking 26 ships for a total of 156,082 GRT, a remarkable average of 39,020 GRT per patrol. In June 1943 Lassen was appointed tactical instructor and commander of the "Offiziers-kompanie" in ''1. U-boot-Lehr-Division'', a training unit for future U-boat commanders. As of 2011, he is the last surviving '''Ace of the Deep''' and among the last living of the most successful Second World War German U-boat commanders.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/lassen.htm |title=''KorvettenkapitÃ¤n'' Georg Lassen |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | <!-- Do NOT place non-free media here --> |- | 11 | [[Joachim Schepke]] | 14 | 37 | 155,882 tons | Joachim Schepke (1912–1941) took command of {{GS|U-3|1935|2}} in 1938, sailed on five combat patrols, and sank two ships. From January to April 1940 he commanded {{GS|U-19|1936|2}}, sinking another nine ships. After a brief spell serving in a staff position Schepke took command of {{GS|U-100|1940|2}} in which he sank another 25 ships. This gave him a total of 37 ships sunk for a total of 155,882 GRT. On 17 March 1941 while attacking [[Convoy HX 112]] ''U-100'' was forced to the surface by [[depth charge]]s from {{HMS|Walker|D27|6}} and {{HMS|Vanoc|H33|6}}, detected on radar, and consequently rammed by ''Vanoc''. Schepke and 37 crewmen were killed; only six were rescued.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/schepke.htm |title=''KapitÃ¤nleutnant'' Joachim Schepke |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | [[File:Joachim Schepke.jpg|100px|Joachim Schepke]] |- | 12 | [[Werner Henke]] | 7 | 24 | 155,714 tons | Werner Henke (1909–1944) took command of {{GS|U-515||2}} in February 1942, sinking 24 ships totaling 155,714 GRT, before ''U-515'' was sunk by [[United States Navy]] aircraft and destroyers north of [[Madeira]]. Henke was taken to a secret interrogation center known only as [[P. O. Box 1142]] in [[Fort Hunt, Virginia]], where his interrogator threatened to send him England to face war crime charges if he did not cooperate. On 15 June 1944, Henke ran to the fence surrounding the interrogation center and began to climb over. He continued after a guard ordered him to stop and was shot and killed.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/henke.htm |title=''KorvettenkapitÃ¤n'' Werner Henke |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 146-1980-115-23A, Werner Henke.jpg|100px|Werner Henke]] |- | 13 | [[Carl Emmermann]] | 5 | 26 | 152,080 tons | Carl Emmermann (1915–1990) took command of {{GS|U-172||2}} in November 1941, completing five patrols, and sinking 26 ships for a total of 152,080 GRT. He became the commander of ''[[6th U-boat Flotilla]]'' in November 1943, and in August 1944 became the chief of the ''Erprobungsgruppe Typ XXIII'' ("[[German Type XXIII submarine|Type XXIII]] Testing Group"). In March-April 1945 Emmermann was commander of {{GS|U-3037||2}}, and in AprilâMay 1945 he commanded ''[[31st U-boat Flotilla]]'' in Hamburg. In the final days of the war he took part in infantry duty around Hamburg as commander of ''Marine-Battalion Emmermann''. After the war he studied engineering and prospered in business.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/emmermann.htm |title=''KorvettenkapitÃ¤n'' Carl Emmermann |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | <!-- Do NOT place non-free media here --> |- | 14 | [[Heinrich Bleichrodt]] | 8 | 24 | 151,260 tons | Heinrich Bleichrodt (1909–1977) was given command of {{GS|U-48|1939|2}} in 1940, sailing on two patrols, and sinking 15 ships totalling 79,295 GRT, including the {{SS|City of Benares}} - an unmarked evacuation transport. After briefly commanding {{GS|U-67|1940|2}}, in June 1941 Bleichrodt took command of {{GS|U-109|1940|2}}. He carried out six patrols, sinking 13 ships for a total of some 80,000 tons, to make a grand total of 24 merchant ships sunk, totalling 151,260 tons. Bleichrodt then served in a training post with ''[[27th U-boat Flotilla]]'' and in the 2nd ULD (U-boat Training Division) as tactical instructor. In July 1944 he was appointed commander of ''[[22nd U-boat Flotilla]]''. After the war become a factory manager.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/bleichrodt.htm |title=''KorvettenkapitÃ¤n'' Heinrich Bleichrodt |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | [[File:Heinrich Bleichrodt.jpg|100px|Heinrich Bleichrodt]] |- | 15 | [[Robert Gysae]] | 8 | 25 | 146,815 tons | Robert Gysae (1911–1989) commanded {{GS|U-98|1940|2}} and {{GS|U-177||2}}, sinking 25 ships for a total on 146,815 GRT in eight patrols. In January 1944 he became commander of training unit ''[[25th U-boat Flotilla]]''. In April 1945, during the last month of the war, Gysae commanded the ''Marinepanzerjagd-Regiment 1'', a naval anti-tank regiment. After the war he served in the ''Deutscher MinenrÃ¤umdienst'' ("[[German Mine Sweeping Administration]]") for more than two years. In 1956 he joined the ''Bundesmarine'', retiring in 1970 with the rank of ''[[Flottillenadmiral]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/gysae.htm |title=''KorvettenkapitÃ¤n'' Robert Gysae |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | [[File:GYSAERobert.jpg|100px|Robert Gysae]] |- | 16 | [[Ernst Kals]] | 5 | 20 | 145,656 tons | Ernst Kals (1905–1979) took command of {{GS|U-130|1941|2}} in June 1941, and sank 20 ships on five patrols, for a total of 145,656 tons of Allied shipping. On 12 November 1942 during the [[Naval Battle of Casablanca]], he attacked the heavily guarded transport ships in [[MohammÃ©dia|Fedala Roads]] in Morocco, sinking three large troop ships for a total of 34,507 tons in five minutes. In January 1943 he became commander of ''[[2nd U-boat Flotilla]]'', where he remained to the end of the war. From May 1945 to January 1948 Kals was held in French captivity.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/kals.htm |title=''KapitÃ¤n zur See'' Ernst Kals |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | <!-- Do NOT place non-free media here --> |- | 17 | [[Johann Mohr]] | 6 | 27 | 129,292 tons | Johann Mohr (1916–1943) assumed command of {{GS|U-124|1940|2}} in September 1941, and sank 27 ships on six patrols, for a total of 129,292 GRT of Allied shipping. This includes four ships from Convoy ONS-92 sunk on the night of 12 May 1942, totalling 21,784 tons. Mohr was killed when ''U-124'' was sunk with all hands on 2 April 1943 west of [[Oporto]], Portugal, by the British [[Flower-class corvette|corvette]] {{HMS|Stonecrop|K142|6}} and the [[Black Swan class sloop|sloop]] {{HMS|Black Swan|L57|6}}.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/mohr.htm |title=''KorvettenkapitÃ¤n'' Johann Mohr |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | [[File:JohannMohr.jpg|100px|Johann Mohr]] |- | 18 | [[Klaus Scholtz]] | 8 | 25 | 128,190 tons | Klaus Scholtz (1908–1987) commanded {{GS|U-108|1940|2}} from October 1940, sinking 25 ships on 8 patrols, for a total of 128,190 tons of Allied shipping. In October 1942 he formed and took command of ''[[12th U-boat Flotilla]]''. In August 1944 he attempted to lead his men back to Germany on foot, but they captured by American forces, and he spent the next 18 months in US captivity. Scholtz served in the [[Bundesgrenzschutz|Bundesgrenzschutz-See]] from 1953 to 1956, then transferred to the ''[[Bundesmarine]]'', serving as commander of several naval bases, including [[Kiel]], [[Cuxhaven]], and [[Wilhelmshaven]]. He retired in 1966.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/scholtz.htm |title=''FregattenkapitÃ¤n'' Klaus Scholtz |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | <!-- Do NOT place non-free media here --> |- | 19 | [[Adolf Piening|Adolf Cornelius Piening]] | 8 | 25 | 126,664 tons | Adolf Piening (1910–1984) took command of {{GS|U-155|1941|2}} in June 1941, and sank 25 ships for a total of 126,664 GRT in 8 patrols. From March 1944 Piening was the commander of ''[[7th U-boat Flotilla]]''. Piening made his last patrol in April 1945, laying mines off [[Saint-Nazaire]] in {{GS|U-255||2}}. After the war Piening spent more than two years in Allied captivity. In 1956 he joined the ''[[Bundesmarine]]'', serving for 13 years.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/piening.htm |title=''KorvettenkapitÃ¤n'' Adolf Cornelius Piening |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | <!-- Do NOT place non-free media here --> |- | 20 | [[Helmut Witte]] | 4 | 23 | 119,554 tons | Helmut Witte (1915–2005) commissioned {{GS|U-159|1941|2}} in October 1941 and in four patrols sank 23 ships totalling 119,554 GRT. From June 1943 he served in several staff positions. At the end of the war he spent two months in British captivity, then became a farm hand and factory worker. Later he had a successful business career.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/witte.htm |title=''KorvettenkapitÃ¤n'' Helmut Witte |work=uboat.net |accessdate=18 April 2010 }}</ref> | <!-- Do NOT place non-free media here --> |- | 21 | [[GÃ¼nther Hessler]] | 3 | 21 | 118,822 tons | GÃ¼nther Hessler (1909–1968) commissioned {{GS|U-107|1940|2}} in 1940, and on his first patrol sank four ships for a total of 18,514 tons. He became famous for his second patrol - the most successful of the entire war - sinking 14 ships for a total of 86,699 tons. His third patrol accounted for another three ships for a total of 13,641 tons, giving Hessler grand total of 21 ships sunk totalling 118,822 GRT. Hessler then transferred to the [[Befehlshaber der U-Boote|BdU]] to serve on the staff of his [[father-in-law]] [[Karl DÃ¶nitz]]. After the war Hessler spent over a year in Allied captivity, and testified at the [[Nuremberg Trials]]. In 1947 Hessler was commissioned by the British [[Royal Navy]] to write ''The U-Boat War in the Atlantic''. Assisted by Alfred Hoschatt, former BdU staff officer and commander of ''U-378'', he completed the three volume work in 1951.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/hessler.htm |title=''FregattenkapitÃ¤n'' GÃ¼nter Hessler |work=uboat.net |accessdate=19 April 2010 }}</ref> |- | 22 | [[Ernst Bauer (KapitÃ¤n zur See)|Ernst Bauer]] | 5 | 25 | 118,560 tons | Ernst Bauer (1914–1988) was given command of {{GS|U-126|1940|2}} in March 1941, and conducted five combat patrols, sinking 25 merchant ships for a total of 118,560 GRT. In October 1944 he became commander of the training unit ''[[27th U-boat Flotilla]]'', and during the last month of war he was transferred to ''[[26th U-boat Flotilla]]''. Bauer rejoined the ''[[Bundesmarine]]'' in 1956 and held several staff positions before retiring in 1972.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/bauer.htm |title=''KorvettenkapitÃ¤n'' Ernst Bauer |work=uboat.net |accessdate=19 April 2010 }}</ref> | |- | 23 | [[Engelbert Endrass]] | 10 | 22 | 118,528 tons | Engelbert Endrass (1911–1941) was 1.WO of {{GS|U-47|1938|2}} when [[GÃ¼nther Prien]] took her into [[Scapa Flow]] and sank {{HMS|Royal Oak|08|6}}. In May 1940 Endrass took command of {{GS|U-46|1938|2}}, and in eight war patrols sank 21 ships, before taking over {{GS|U-567||2}} in October 1941. He sank only one more ship, making 22 ships sunk totalling 118,528 tons in 10 patrols. He was killed when ''U-567'' was sunk with all hands on 21 December 1941, by depth charges from the British [[Grimsby class sloop|sloop]] {{HMS|Deptford|U53|6}} and [[Flower class corvette|corvette]] {{HMS|Samphire|K128|6}}, northeast of the [[Azores]].<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/endrass.htm |title=''KapitÃ¤nleutnant'' Engelbert Endrass |work=uboat.net |accessdate=19 April 2010 }}</ref> | <!-- Do NOT place non-free media here --> |- | 24 | [[Reinhard Hardegen]] | 5 | 22 | 115,656 tons | Reinhard Hardegen (1913–) took command of {{GS|U-147|1940|2}} in 1940 for a single patrol, then {{GS|U-123|1940|2}} for another four patrols in 1941, sinking 22 merchant ships for a total of 115,656 GRT. In mid-1942, he became an instructor in ''[[27th U-boat Flotilla]]'', and from March 1943, served as chief of the torpedo school at ''Marineschule MÃ¼rwik''. Hardegen served for few months in the ''Torpedowaffenamt'' (Torpedo Weapon Department) before serving as Battalion Commander in ''Marine Infanterie Regiment 6'' from February 1945, taking part in the fighting around Bremen. Hardegen spent a year and a half in British captivity before starting a successful oil trading business, as well as serving as a member of Bremen's [[Landtag|city council]] (the ''[[BÃ¼rgerschaft of Bremen|BÃ¼rgerschaft]]'') for 32 years.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/hardegen.htm |title=''KorvettenkapitÃ¤n'' Reinhard Hardegen |work=uboat.net |accessdate=19 April 2010 }}</ref> | <!-- Do NOT place non-free media here --> |- |25 | [[Werner Hartmann]] | 4 | 26 | 115,337 tons | Werner Hartmann (1902–1963) was commander of both {{GS|U-37|1938|2}} and ''[[2nd U-boat Flotilla]]'' from January–May 1940, but this proved inefficient, and [[Befehlshaber der U-Boote|BdU]] decided to direct the U-boats from land. After three patrols, and sinking 19 ships totalling 78,559 GRT, Hartmann moved to the BdU staff. In November 1940 he became commander of ''2. Unterseeboots-Lehr-Division'' ("2nd U-boat Training Division"), and a year later took command of the ''[[27th U-boat Flotilla]]''. In November 1942 he took command of {{GS|U-198||2}} for a patrol to the Indian Ocean lasting 200 days, the third longest patrol ever undertaken, and sank 7 ships totalling 36,778 GRT, giving him a grand total of 26 ships sunk for 115,337 tons. In 1944 Hartmann became ''[[FÃ¼hrer der U-Boote|FdU]] Mittelmeer'' ("Commander of U-boats in the Mediterranean"). After the war he spent several years in the ''[[Bundesmarine]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/hartmann.htm |title=''KapitÃ¤n zur See'' Werner Hartmann |work=uboat.net |accessdate=19 April 2010 }}</ref> |[[File:Werner.hartmann.jpg|100px|Werner Hartmann]] |- | 26 | [[Hans Jenisch]] | 6 | 17 | 110,139 tons | Hans Jenisch (1913–1982) took command of {{GS|U-32|1937|2}} in early 1940. During six patrols he sank 17 ships, including the 42,348 ton {{RMS|Empress of Britain|1931|6}}, the largest ship sunk by a U-boat, for a career total of 110,139 GRT. Jenisch was taken prisoner in October 1940 when ''U-32'' was sunk north-west of Ireland by two British destroyers. He then spent six and a half years in British captivity. In 1956 he joined the ''[[Bundesmarine]]'', holding mainly staff positions, but also commanding the [[Black Swan class sloop|frigate]] ''Hipper'' for a few months. He retired in 1972.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/jenisch.htm |title=''KapitÃ¤nleutnant'' Hans Jenisch |work=uboat.net |accessdate=19 April 2010 }}</ref> | |- | 27 | [[Robert-Richard Zapp]] | 5 | 16 | 106,200 tons | Robert-Richard Zapp (1904–1964) served on one patrol in {{GS|U-46|1938|2}} under [[Engelbert Endrass]], before taking command of {{GS|U-66|1940|2}} in January 1941. In five patrols, including two as part of "[[Second Happy Time|Operation Drumbeat]]", he sank 16 ships for a total of 106,200 GRT. Zapp became commander of ''[[3rd U-boat Flotilla]]'' in June 1942. The flotilla was disbanded in October 1944, and he then commanded ''Marine Regiment Zapp'', defending the U-boat base, until May 1945. He then spent more than two years in French captivity.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/zapp.htm |title=''FregattenkapitÃ¤n'' Richard Zapp |work=uboat.net |accessdate=19 April 2010 }}</ref> | <!-- Do NOT place non-free media here --> |- | 28 | [[Victor Oehrn]] | 4 | 23 | 103,821 tons | Victor Oehrn (1907–1997) became commander of {{GS|U-14|1936|2}} in January 1936, patrolling during the [[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]] in July–September 1936. In August 1939 he joined the staff of [[Befehlshaber der U-Boote|BdU]]. In May 1940 Oehrn took command of {{GS|U-37|1938|2}}, in order to restore the U-boat men's trust in the [[G7e torpedo#G7e/T2|G7e/T2 torpedo]], which had performed abysmally, often detonating prematurely, or not at all. In four patrols he sank 23 ships for a total of 103,821 GRT before returning to the staff in August. From November 1941 Oehrn served on the Mediterranean U-boat staff, but during a mission to [[North Africa]] in July 1942, he was severely wounded and captured by the British. He was released in a [[prisoner exchange]] in October 1943 and returned to Germany. Oehrn spent the remainder of the war serving in several staff positions.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/oehrn.htm |title=''FregattenkapitÃ¤n'' Victor Oehrn |work=uboat.net |accessdate=19 April 2010 }}</ref> | |- | 29 | [[JÃ¼rgen Oesten]] | 13 | 19 | 101,744 tons | JÃ¼rgen Oesten (1913–2010) , commanded {{GS|U-61|1939|2}} on nine patrols, and sank five ships, before commanding {{GS|U-106|1940|2}} on three patrols, and sinking another ten ships. In October 1941 he became the commander of the ''[[9th U-boat Flotilla]]'' based in [[Brest, France]]. In March 1942 Oesten joined the staff of ''[[FÃ¼hrer der U-Boote|FdU]] Nordmeer'' directing the U-boat war in Arctic waters, but returned to U-boat duty in September 1943, sailing {{GS|U-861||2}} to [[Penang]] to join the ''[[Monsun Gruppe]]'', and sinking another four ships, bringing his total to 19 ships sunk, totalling 101,744 GRT. ''U-861'' left [[Surabaya|Soerabaya]], [[Dutch East Indies]], in January 1945 and reached [[Trondheim]], Norway, in April, just before the [[Victory in Europe Day|German surrender]].<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/oesten.htm |title=''KorvettenkapitÃ¤n'' JÃ¼rgen Oesten |work=uboat.net |accessdate=19 April 2010 }}</ref> Oesten was the technical advisor for the 2005 [[submarine simulator]] ''[[Silent Hunter III]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://news.softpedia.com/news/Softpedia-News-talks-with-the-creators-of-Silent-Hunter-III-2142.shtml |title=Softpedia News talks with the creators of ''Silent Hunter III'' |work=news.softpedia.com |accessdate=19 April 2010 }}</ref> | |- | 30 | [[Wilhelm Rollmann]] | 8 | 22 | 101,519 tons | Rollmann (1907–1943) took command of {{GS|U-34|1936|2}} in October 1938. After seven successful patrols Rollmann became an instructor in ''2. Unterseeboots-Lehr-Division'' ("2nd U-boat Training Division"). In February 1943 he commissioned {{GS|U-848||2}}, sinking one ship of 4,573 tons on his first and only patrol, bringing his career total to 22 ships sunk for 101,519 tons. Rollmann and his crew were all killed on 5 November 1943 when ''U-848'' was sunk by US aircraft south-west of [[Ascension Island|Ascension]] in the mid-Atlantic.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/rollmann.htm |title=''FregattenkapitÃ¤n'' Wilhelm Rollmann |work=uboat.net |accessdate=20 April 2010 }}</ref> | |- |31 | [[Erwin Rostin]] | 2 | 17 | 101,321 tons | Erwin Rostin (1907–1942) sailed on his first war patrol as commander of {{GS|U-158|1941|2}} in February 1942, and sank four ships for a total of 29,234 tons off the US east coast. His second patrol began in May 1942 and was one of the most successful patrols of the war, with 12 ships sunk for a total of 62,536 tons, giving him a career total of 17 ships sunk for 101,321 tons. Rostin and his crew were killed on 30 June 1942 when the U-boat was sunk by a United States Navy [[PBM Mariner|Mariner]] bomber.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/rostin.htm |title=''KapitÃ¤nleutnant'' Erwin Rostin |work=uboat.net |accessdate=20 April 2010 }}</ref> | |- | 32 | [[Hans Witt|Hans-Ludwig Witt]] | 3 | 19 | 100,773 tons | Hans-Ludwig Witt (1909–1980) took command of {{GS|U-161|1941|2}} in 1941 as part of a training flotilla, before transferring to command of {{GS|U-129|1941|2}} in 1942. Witt sailed on three successful patrols in the western Atlantic and the Caribbean in 1942 and 1943, sinking 19 ships for a total of 100,773 GRT. After a year on the [[BdU]] staff, he returned to active duty in 1945 in {{GS|U-3524||2}}, one of the new [[German Type XXI submarine|Type XXI]] ''Elektroboote'', but sailed on no combat patrols.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://uboat.net/men/witt.htm |title=''KorvettenkapitÃ¤n'' Hans-Ludwig Witt |work=uboat.net |accessdate=20 April 2010 }}</ref> | |- | 33 | [[GÃ¼nther Krech]] | 10 | 19 | 100,771 tons | GÃ¼nther Krech (1914–2000) commissioned {{GS|U-558||2}} in February 1941, and in ten patrols, mostly in the Atlantic and in Caribbean waters, sank 19 merchant ships for a total of 100,771 tons. ''U-558'' was sunk by US aircraft on 20 July 1943 in the [[Bay of Biscay]]. Only Krech, the LI (engineer officer) and three men of the gun crew survived. Krech remained in Allied captivity until after the war.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://uboat.net/men/krech.htm |title=''KapitÃ¤nleutnant'' GÃ¼nther Krech |work=uboat.net |accessdate=20 April 2010 }}</ref> | |- | 34 | [[Harald Gelhaus]] | 11 | 19 | 100,373 tons | Harald Gelhaus (1915–1997) commanded {{GS|U-143|1940|2}} and {{GS|U-107|1940|2}}, sailing in ten patrols between March 1941 and June 1943, and sinking 19 ships for a total of 100,373 tons. He then joined the staff of the [[Oberkommando der Marine|OKM]], the High Command of the German Navy. From February 1944, he was a training officer in ''[[22nd U-boat Flotilla|22]]'' and ''[[27th U-boat Flotilla]]''. He spent the final months of the war in staff positions, the last one being in Naval High Command North. After the war he spent three months in Allied captivity.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://uboat.net/men/gelhaus.htm |title=''KapitÃ¤nleutnant'' Harald Gelhaus |work=uboat.net |accessdate=22 April 2010 }}</ref> | |- | 35 | [[Werner Hartenstein]] | 5 | 20 | 97,504 tons | Werner Hartenstein (1908–1943) commissioned {{GS|U-156|1941|2}} in September 1941. In five patrols he sank 20 ships for a total of 97,504 tons. On the second patrol Hartenstein attacked the refinery at [[Aruba]] with gunfire. On the fourth patrol he was involved in the [[Laconia incident]]. During the fifth patrol, on 8 March 1943, Hartenstein and all his crew were killed when ''U-156'' was sunk by depth charges dropped from a United States Navy [[PBY Catalina]], east of the island of [[Barbados]].<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://uboat.net/men/hartenstein.htm |title=''KorvettenkapitÃ¤n'' Werner Hartenstein |work=uboat.net |accessdate=22 April 2010 }}</ref> | |- | 36 | [[Fritz-Julius Lemp]] | 10 | 20 | 96,639 tons | Fritz-Julius Lemp (1913–1941) commanded {{GS|U-30|1936|2}} and {{GS|U-110|1940|2}} on 10 patrols, sinking 20 ships totalling 96,639 tons. His first attack, on 3 September 1939, only two days after the British declaration of war, was the most controversial. Lemp sank what he thought was an [[armed merchant cruiser]], but was in fact the passenger liner {{SS|Athenia}}; 112 of her passengers died. The sinking caused dramatic publicity throughout the English-speaking world, while the German High Command systematically attempted to cover up this appalling error. Not until January 1946, during the Nuremberg Trials, did Admiral DÃ¶nitz finally admit that ''Athenia'' had been torpedoed by ''U-30''. Lemp was killed in May 1941 when ''U-110'', on her second patrol, was captured east of [[Cape Farewell, Greenland]], by the British [[destroyers]] {{HMS|Bulldog|H91|6}} and [[USS Hunt (DD-194)|HMS ''Broadway'']].<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://uboat.net/men/lemp.htm |title=''KapitÃ¤nleutnant'' Fritz-Julius Lemp |work=uboat.net |accessdate=29 April 2010 }}</ref> |[[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 101II-MN-1365-27A, Lemp und DÃ¶nitz im GesprÃ¤ch.jpg|100px|Fritz-Julius Lemp]] |- |37 | [[Adalbert Schnee]] | 12 | 23 | 96,547 tons | Adalbert Schnee (1913–1982) commanded {{GS|U-6|1935|2}}, {{GS|U-60|1939|2}}, {{GS|U-201||2}} in 11 patrols, sinking 21 merchant ships totalling 90,189 tons, and damaged three others (28,820 tons). He also sank two British auxiliary warships, {{HMS|Springbank||2}} and {{HMS|Laertes|T137|2}}. After serving on the [[Befehlshaber der U-Boote|BdU]] staff from October 1942, Schnee took command of the [[German Type XXI submarine|Type XXI]] {{GS|U-2511||2}}, in September 1944, sailing on only a single short patrol between 3 and 6 May 1945 before surrendering.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://uboat.net/men/schnee.htm |title=''KorvettenkapitÃ¤n'' Adalbert Schnee |work=uboat.net |accessdate=29 April 2010 }}</ref> | <!-- Do NOT place non-free media here --> |- | 38 | [[Reinhard Suhren]] | 6 | 18 | 95,544 tons | | [[File:Reinhard Suhren.jpg|100px|Reinhard Suhren]] |- | 39 | [[Karl-Heinz Moehle]] | 10 | 21 | 93,197 tons | | <!-- Do NOT place non-free media here --> |- | 40 | [[Georg-Wilhelm Schulz]] | 8 | 19 | 89,886 tons | | <!-- Do NOT place non-free media here --> |- | 41 | [[Georg Schewe]] | 10 | 16 | 85,779 tons | | |- | 42 | [[Fritz Poske|Hans-Georg Friedrich Poske]] | 4 | 16 | 85,299 tons | | |- | 43 | [[Ulrich Heyse]] | 5 | 12 | 83,639 tons | | |- | 44 | [[Ulrich Folkers]] | 5 | 17 | 82,873 tons | | |- | 45 | [[Herbert Kuppisch]] | 14 | 16 | 82,108 tons | | [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 101II-MW-3495-04, Uboot U 96, Herbert Kuppisch.jpg|100px|Herbert Kuppisch]] |- | 46 | [[JÃ¼rgen Wattenberg]] | 3 | 14 | 82,027 tons | |- | 47 | [[Rolf MÃ¼tzelburg]] | 8 | 19 | 81,987 tons | | [[File:MUTZELBURG.jpg|100px|Rolf MÃ¼tzelburg]] |- | 48 | [[Werner Winter]] | 5 | 15 | 79,302 tons | | |- | 49 | [[Fritz Frauenheim]] | 9 | 19 | 78,853 tons | | <!-- Do NOT place non-free media here --> |- | 50 | [[JÃ¼rgen von Rosenstiel]] | 4 | 14 | 78,843 tons | JÃ¼rgen von Rosenstiel (1912–1942), commander of {{GS|U-502||2}}, sank 14 ships for a total of 78,843 GRT in only four patrols. On the last of these, on 5 July 1942, ''U-502'' was sunk by a British [[Vickers Wellington|Wellington]] bomber in the [[Bay of Biscay]]. Rosenstiel and his crew were all killed.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/men/rosenstiel.htm |title=''KapitÃ¤nleutnant'' JÃ¼rgen von Rosenstiel |work=uboat.net |accessdate=19 April 2010 }}</ref> | |}
